item.title: Late Night Finds Trump Out of Place at Prayer Breakfast
item.description: The annual National Prayer Breakfast “is supposed to be a normal, nonpartisan event,” Seth Meyers said, “but, of course, Donald Trump is incapable of being normal.”
item.dc:creator: Trish Bendix
item.category: Late Show with Stephen Colbert (TV Program)
Late Night with Seth Meyers (TV Program)

item.title: Palabra del día: ‘heinous’
item.description: Esta palabra ha aparecido en 144 artículos en NYTimes.com en el último año. ¿Puedes usarla en una frase?
item.dc:creator: The Learning Network

item.title: Así usaba Epstein los regalos para afianzar relaciones
item.description: Desde relojes inteligentes hasta prendas de alta gama, los obsequios servían para consolidar vínculos con personas de su círculo cercano.
item.dc:creator: Jacob Gallagher

media:content.media:credit: Neil Rasmus/Patrick McMullan, vía Getty Images
media:content.media:description: Jeffrey Epstein era fotografiado a menudo con una sudadera con cremallera con sus iniciales, JEE Como muchos miembros de la élite neoyorquina, se sentía atraído por los productos personalizados.

item.title: Word of the Day: heinous
item.description: This word has appeared in 144 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
item.dc:creator: The Learning Network

item.title: A petición de Ucrania, Starlink bloquea el acceso a internet de las tropas rusas
item.description: El corte del servicio de la empresa de Elon Musk es el último giro en una guerra de casi cuatro años que ha estado dominada por una implacable carrera por la supremacía tecnológica.
item.dc:creator: Paul Sonne and Maria Varenikova

media:content.media:credit: Reuters
media:content.media:description: Un soldado ucraniano prepara un sistema de internet por satélite Starlink en la región de Donetsk en 2024. Los rusos han estado eludiendo las restricciones

item.title: Este periodista trabajó 60 años en el Washington Post. Acaba de ser despedido
item.description: Los despidos del Post, que afectan a más de 300 periodistas, han impactado duramente en la sección de noticias locales, donde Martin Weil trabajaba desde 1965.
item.dc:creator: Erik Wemple

media:content.media:credit: Jason Andrew for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: The thrill of a byline in The Washington Post “never went away,” said Martin Weil, at his home in the city.

item.title: America’s Rare-Earths Solution Is Hiding in Plain Sight
item.description: The real threat to a secure and sustainable supply of rare earths is not that they are scarce, but that so much is wasted.
item.dc:creator: Julie Michelle Klinger

item.title: The Globalization of Canadian Rage
item.description: The world is angry. Canada’s been there all along.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Marche

media:content.media:credit: James Park/Reuters

item.title: New Jersey House Primary Remains Too Close to Call
item.description: Two Democrats, Analilia Mejia and Tom Malinowski, were leading in a race for their party’s nomination to replace Gov. Mikie Sherrill in the House.
item.dc:creator: Tracey Tully

media:content.media:credit: Rachel Wisniewski for The New York Times, Brian Fraser for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Analilia Mejia and Tom Malinowski were leading in a race for their party’s nomination to replace Gov. Mikie Sherrill in the House.

item.title: She’s Upending Japanese Politics With Two Words: ‘I’m Pregnant’
item.description: Hikaru Fujita, who’s running in Sunday’s parliamentary election, is a standout in a country where expectant mothers rarely enter national politics.
item.dc:creator: Javier C. Hernández and Kiuko Notoya

media:content.media:credit: Noriko Hayashi for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Hikaru Fujita, a candidate for Parliament, in Azumino City, Nagano Prefecture, on Tuesday.

item.title: El costo político de acabar con el narcotráfico en México
item.description: El problema no es simplemente que los grupos de narcotraficantes ataquen al Estado. Es que a menudo forman parte de él.
item.dc:creator: Mary Beth Sheridan

media:content.media:credit: Guillermo Arias/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images

item.title: The Olympics Are a Show Of Global Harmony. The World is Anything But.
item.description: The Winter Games, which officially open in Italy on Friday, are rooted in international cooperation. That feels out of place to some in a world where old rules no longer apply.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich

media:content.media:credit: Gabriela Bhaskar/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: The Olympic rings in Livigno, Italy.

item.title: An Indian Film Embraces a Taj Majal Conspiracy Theory
item.description: The internet and a new film have breathed life into old conspiracy theories about one of the world’s most famous landmarks.
item.dc:creator: Steven Lee Myers and Saumya Khandelwal

item.title: Milan Winter Olympics Opening Ceremony: How to Watch, Timing and More
item.description: They will take place at 2 p.m. Eastern on Friday across four separate venues in Northern Italy.
item.dc:creator: Ashley Ahn

media:content.media:credit: Gabriela Bhaskar/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: A training session at Livigno Snow Park in Italy on Wednesday.

item.title: U.S. and Iran Set for Talks in Oman
item.description: Middle Eastern diplomats see a chance for negotiations on Iran’s nuclear program but have slim hopes for progress on other U.S. demands.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon and Ben Hubbard

media:content.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: A billboard at a square in Tehran last month portrayed a strike on a U.S. carrier.

item.title: When They Were Broken Up, They Communicated Through Playlists
item.description: Daniel Schwaycer quietly made playlists about Elise Shanholtz. It took two years for her to realize they were about her.
item.dc:creator: Ama Sarpomaa

item.title: Seeking a Man Who Doesn’t Throw Tantrums
item.description: I had set my bar for relationships so low that any man who didn’t yell easily cleared it.
item.dc:creator: Denise Mills

media:content.media:credit: Brian Rea

item.title: Brock McGillis, Former Professional Hockey Player, Marries Matthew Ward After a Decade of Ups and Downs
item.description: Brock McGillis, a former professional hockey player who came out as gay in 2016, married Matthew Ward after a decade of ups and downs.
item.dc:creator: Sadiba Hasan

media:content.media:credit: Steph Martyniuk for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Brock McGillis, left, and Matthew Ward were married on Jan. 30 at the Windsor Arms Hotel in Toronto. The two connected in early 2016. Later that year, Mr. McGillis, a retired hockey player, came out publicly.

item.title: More Than a Decade Later, Nina Russell and Mainak Ghosh Found Each Other Again
item.description: Nina Russell and Mainak Ghosh met at a literary club at Yale. They wouldn’t become a couple until more than a decade later.
item.dc:creator: Stella Raine Chu

item.title: They Were Always On the Right Path
item.description: Dr. Peter Anderson, who had hiked 1,000 miles of the Appalachian Trail, helped Olivia Bergen prepare for her 2,200-mile solo trek.
item.dc:creator: Rosalie R. Radomsky

item.title: Texas Surgeon Faces Federal Charges That He Falsified Patient Records
item.description: Prosecutors said the doctor, John Stevenson Bynon Jr., had cut five patients off from liver transplant eligibility for months without their knowledge. He has pleaded not guilty.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra E. Petri

media:content.media:credit: Matt Patterson, via Associated Press
media:content.media:description: Memorial Hermann-Texas Medical Center in Houston, where Dr. John Stevenson Bynon Jr. led liver and kidney transplant programs.

item.title: Muslims Move to Assert Political Power in New York City
item.description: Zohran Mamdani’s ascension to mayor has given Muslim organizers and faith leaders the impetus to insert themselves into more formal political alliances and networks.
item.dc:creator: Maya King

media:content.media:credit: Graham Dickie for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: On Thursday, a group consisting mostly of Muslim organizers and faith leaders in the Bronx voted to join the Metro Industrial Areas Foundation, one of the nation’s oldest nonpartisan organizing networks.

item.title: Argentina and U.S. Sign Sweeping Trade Deal as Alliance Deepens
item.description: The deal reduces reciprocal tariffs and expands quotas for key trading goods, including Argentine beef — a flashpoint for American ranchers.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola

media:content.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: President Trump with President Javier Milei of Argentina at the White House in October.

item.title: ‘The Pitt’ Season 2, Episode 5 Recap: Reunited
item.description: Robby and Langdon finally collide, and the vibe is predictably tense. That sabbatical can’t some soon enough.
item.dc:creator: Sean T. Collins

media:content.media:credit: Warrick Page/HBO Max
media:content.media:description: Dr. Robby and Dr. Langdon (Noah Wyle, left, and Patrick Ball) were thrown back together by a very scary case. Prognosis: touch-and-go.

item.title: NYT Crossword Answers for Feb. 6, 2026
item.description: Geoffrey Schorkopf and Rafael Musa open our solving weekend.
item.dc:creator: Sam Corbin

item.title: Smithsonian Folklife Festival Gives Way to Trump’s Patriotic Fair
item.description: The summer festival, held annually since 1967, will not take place as usual on the National Mall, which will instead host the president’s Great American State Fair.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Schuessler

media:content.media:credit: Ralph Rinzler Archives/Smithsonian
media:content.media:description: A traditional Inuit blanket toss at the Smithsonian Folklife Festival in 1974.

item.title: ‘The Mistake of Feminism’
item.description: Is it possible to support women while also opposing abortion? The pro-life activist Lila Rose argues yes. The key, she says, is to acknowledge that men and women are inherently different.

media:content.media:credit: The New York Times

item.title: Who Decides When a Pregnancy Is Life-Threatening?
item.description: Strict abortion bans can be at odds with emergency medical care. The pro-life activist Lila Rose argues they can coexist.

media:content.media:credit: The New York Times

item.title: No Corrections: Feb. 6, 2026
item.description: No corrections appeared in print on Friday, Feb. 6, 2026.

item.title: TrumpRx, the President’s Online Drugstore, Opens for Business
item.description: TrumpRx is aimed at helping patients use their own money to buy medicines. But researchers who study drug pricing warned that many patients could pay too much if they use the site.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Robbins and Margot Sanger-Katz

media:content.media:credit: Eric Thayer/Getty Images
media:content.media:description: The TrumpRx website is meant to be an entry point for consumers to search for their medicines and then direct them to manufacturers’ websites to buy the drugs directly.

item.title: Las criptomonedas se desploman, a pesar del apoyo de Trump
item.description: El bitcóin cotiza a menos de 64.000 dólares, un descenso de casi el 50 por ciento desde su precio máximo, que alcanzó justo el pasado octubre.
item.dc:creator: David Yaffe-Bellany

item.title: N.Y. House Democrats Unite to Endorse Hochul on Eve of Convention
item.description: Gov. Kathy Hochul is expected to receive the Democratic nomination at the party’s state convention on Friday, even as her running-mate selection has drawn some debate.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Oreskes

media:content.media:credit: Liam Kennedy for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Gov. Kathy Hochul on Thursday made her first appearance with Adrienne Adams since naming her as her running mate on the Democratic ticket.

item.title: Hundreds of Immigration Agents Left Minnesota, but Residents Report Little Change
item.description: The Trump administration announced that its deployment of immigration agents in the Twin Cities was diminishing, but many agents remain.
item.dc:creator: Julie Bosman and Talya Minsberg

media:content.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Community members filled the sidewalks, blowing whistles and filming with their phones, as about 20 federal agents gathered in Minneapolis on Thursday.

item.title: Uber Found Liable in Rape by Driver, Setting Stage for Thousands of Cases
item.description: In a federal bellwether case, the jury ordered the ride-hailing giant to pay $8.5 million to Jaylynn Dean, who said one of its drivers assaulted her in 2023.
item.dc:creator: Emily Steel

media:content.media:credit: Caitlin O'Hara for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Jaylynn Dean at a hotel in Phoenix, where a federal jury awarded her damages on Thursday.

item.title: 12 Columbia Professors and Students Are Arrested at Anti-ICE Protest
item.description: Demonstrators, who were demanding that the university provide more protection for international students, blocked Broadway.
item.dc:creator: Sharon Otterman and Olivia Bensimon

media:content.media:credit: Marco Postigo Storel for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: About 150 protesters called on Columbia to strengthen protections for international students.

item.title: Virginia Democrats Propose New Congressional Maps Ahead of Midterms
item.description: As they appeal a ruling blocking their redistricting efforts, the state’s Democrats proposed redrawing districts in a way that would strongly favor them.
item.dc:creator: Nick Corasaniti and Reid J. Epstein

media:content.media:credit: Mike Kropf/Richmond Times-Dispatch via Associated Press
media:content.media:description: Virginia’s proposed congressional map is one of the most significant moves by Democrats in the national redistricting arms race that has engulfed about a dozen states over the past year.

item.title: Failure to Alert Judge to Press Law for Reporter Search Draws Ethical Scrutiny
item.description: The Justice Department may have violated a candor rule by not disclosing a 1980 law when seeking a warrant for a Washington Post reporter’s home.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage

media:content.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: The Washington Post headquarters. Specialists in legal ethics said that if the prosecutor who submitted the application knew about the law, the failure to bring it up violated a longstanding legal ethics rule.

item.title: Lawmakers Say They Will Not Cooperate With Inquiry Into Illegal Orders Video
item.description: The Justice Department investigation was an escalation in the administration’s response to a video that President Trump said was “punishable by death.”
item.dc:creator: Megan Mineiro

media:content.media:credit: Eric Lee/Getty Images

item.title: Pentagon Official Rejects Plea Deal in U.S.S. Cole Bombing Case
item.description: The decision clears the way for the first death-penalty trial at Guantánamo Bay to start this summer, more than 25 years after the attack.
item.dc:creator: Carol Rosenberg
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

media:content.media:credit: Hasan Jamali/Associated Press
media:content.media:description: The U.S.S. Cole at a Yemeni harbor in October 2000, more than two weeks after an attack by Al Qaeda suicide bombers killed 17 sailors and wounded dozens of others.

item.title: C.I.A. World Factbook Ends Publication After 6 Decades
item.description: The Factbook, a version of which dates to 1962, provided facts, figures, maps and more to generations of economists, professors, journalists and others.
item.dc:creator: Rylee Kirk and Mark Walker

media:content.media:credit: Drew Angerer for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: The “Kryptos” sculpture in a courtyard at the C.I.A. campus. The C.I.A.’s World Factbook was shut down on Thursday.

item.title: Trump Calls for New Treaty as Nuclear Arms Control Era Ends
item.description: Also, Trump expanded his power to fire federal workers. Here’s the latest at the end of Thursday.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Cullen

media:content.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: President Trump with President Vladimir Putin of Russia in Alaska last year.

item.title: Toronto Police Charged in Sweeping Drug and Corruption Case
item.description: After hit men targeted the home of a prison manager in June, investigators say, the schemes of a criminal network involving the police unraveled.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai

media:content.media:credit: Jon Blacker/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
media:content.media:description: From left, Chief Myron Demkiw of the Toronto police, Chief Jim MacSween and Deputy Chief Ryan Hogan of the York Regional Police at a news conference on Thursday in Aurora, Ontario.

item.title: Toronto Police Officers Charged in Drug and Corruption Investigation
item.description: Eight Toronto police officers were charged in an investigation, which began after a prison manager was targeted by three hit men. The investigation unraveled a crime network and revealed a connection to the police officers who have been accused of participating in organized criminal activity and drug trafficking.
item.dc:creator: Meg Felling

media:content.media:credit: Jon Blacker/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
media:content.media:description: From left, Chief Myron Demkiw of the Toronto police, Chief Jim MacSween and Deputy Chief Ryan Hogan of the York Regional Police at a news conference on Thursday in Aurora, Ontario.

item.title: ‘The Strangers: Chapter 3’ Review: Devils in Disguise
item.description: The final installment in the trilogy reboot of “The Strangers,” a genuinely terrifying 2008 home invasion film, brings the masked nonsense to a close.
item.dc:creator: Erik Piepenburg

item.title: At Least 160 Killed in Rural Nigeria Villages, Aid Official Says
item.description: Gunmen killed more than 160 people in two rural villages in Nigeria, according to the Nigerian branch of the Red Cross. The attack was one of the country’s deadliest in recent years.
item.dc:creator: Jackeline Luna

item.title: Family Sues Egypt Over Beating of 2 Brothers at U.N. Mission in New York
item.description: The brothers claim four security guards beat and detained them during a protest in August 2025 outside Egypt’s mission to the United Nations.
item.dc:creator: Maia Coleman

media:content.media:credit: Angelina Katsanis for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Yasin El Sammak and his younger brother sued the Egyptian government, accusing guards at the Egyptian Mission to the United Nations in New York City of beating and detaining them.

item.title: 3 Killed as Vehicle Crashes Into Grocery Store in Los Angeles
item.description: Four other people were taken to a hospital, two with serious injuries and two with minor injuries, officials said.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Ziegler and Orlando Mayorquín

item.title: Senators Clash Over Immigration Enforcement, Risking a D.H.S. Shutdown
item.description: With eight days until a deadline to keep the Department of Homeland Security running, bipartisan talks on reining in federal immigration agents’ tactics appeared to sputter before they had even gotten underway.
item.dc:creator: Michael Gold

media:content.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Senators left Washington for the weekend without opening serious talks on a measure needed to keep the Department of Homeland Security running past a Feb. 13 midnight deadline.

item.title: El alcalde de Tequila, en México, fue detenido y acusado de extorsión
item.description: El presidente municipal fue detenido junto con otros tres funcionarios acusados de extorsionar a empresas cerveceras y tequileras del estado de Jalisco.
item.dc:creator: Emiliano Rodríguez Mega

media:content.media:credit: Lindsay Lauckner Gundlock para The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Agave azul, cultivado para hacer tequila, en el estado de Jalisco, México.

item.title: ‘Moulin Rouge!’ Musical Will End Its Broadway Run This Summer
item.description: The final New York performance will be July 26, seven years after it opened; international and touring productions continue.
item.dc:creator: Michael Paulson

media:content.media:credit: Sara Krulwich/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: The show, which opened in 2019, won the Tony Award for best musical at a pandemic-delayed ceremony held in 2021.
